I have had some contact with biology, although I'm
basically a code monkey with a Ph.D.  I read Darwin's
tome all the way through, even though I didn't know
what half of the species were that he discussed.  In
the early 70's I was on the faculty of biology at San
Diego State University for 4 years; I was their math &
computer guy.  I have no formal education in biology
except for a 10th grade class, but I have long had an
interest in it, so I read the occaisional book and
pick up some info here and there.  I've read "The
Selfish Gene" and several popular biology books.  You
will find me listed in a book called "American Men &
Women of Science", the life sciences edition, 1971. 
That was for project management of a large computer
simulation project.  (Simulating the Arctic Tundra
near Barrow, Alaska)

I want to make a comment on the discussion about
speciation.  We all agree that our field is inspired
by, and largely patterned after, what we know about
biology.  When thinking about this we often think
about the creatures we are most familiar with, namely,
homo sapiens.  In my opinion it is more fruitful to
think about much simpler organisms, such as bacteria,
yeast, algae, etc.  Even those are much more
complicated than our models, but they are closer,
since we don't have sexual reproduction, nor many
other genetic & developmental phenomena found in
nature.  So I think we should model our work after the
simplest organisms that we know something about.


=====
Mitchell Timin
